text: Any chance the <https://github.com/mbauman/InvertedIndices.jl|NegatedIndices à la R> will eventually land in Julia Base rather than on <https://github.com/mbauman/InvertedIndices.jl|a separate package> ? I agree with others that it seems the kind of basic language stuff that looks more pertinent to the core of the language that on a package...

elements.text: Any chance the
NegatedIndices à la R
will eventually land in Julia Base rather than on
a separate package
? I agree with others that it seems the kind of basic language stuff that looks more pertinent to the core of the language that on a package...

text: Unlikely - it works perfectly fine as a package and putting it into base doesn't give any substantial benefits

elements.text: Unlikely - it works perfectly fine as a package and putting it into base doesn't give any substantial benefits

text: on the contrary, it's harder to update it

elements.text: on the contrary, it's harder to update it

text: I tend to disagree that it works perfectly fine. Having to type `using InvertedIndices` for such a basic Feature isn't optimal and annoying.

elements.text: I tend to disagree that it works perfectly fine. Having to type
using InvertedIndices
for such a basic Feature isn't optimal and annoying.

text: I also doubt that there will be / need to be many/any updates.

elements.text: I also doubt that there will be / need to be many/any updates.

text: The last commit is almost 2 years old

elements.text: The last commit is almost 2 years old

text: I really doubt having `Not` exported by default would be a good idea, seems like it would invite name clashes, so that's one argument against that :man-shrugging:

elements.text: I really doubt having
Not
exported by default would be a good idea, seems like it would invite name clashes, so that's one argument against that

text: Just because R has it by default is not a good argument for why julia should also have it by default, imo

elements.text: Just because R has it by default is not a good argument for why julia should also have it by default, imo

text: preventing the name clash would still require you to do `using Base.InvertedIndices`, so that's not more convenient

elements.text: preventing the name clash would still require you to do
using Base.InvertedIndices
, so that's not more convenient

text: reading through the source, it also doesn't seem like it's that easy to implement at all, even though the user interface is deceivingly small

text:
I would be surprised if `Not` caused name-clashes.
Because titlecase is for types.
and `Not` is a weird thing to have a type for.
